contentrichtext.text: [[File:Hannelore Kohl.jpg|thumb|Hannelore Kohl (1976)]] '''Hannelore Kohl''' (7 March 1933, [[Berlin]] – 5 July 2001) was the wife of former [[Germany|German]] [[Chancellor of Germany (Federal Republic)|Chancellor]] [[Helmut Kohl]]. She met him for the first time at a prom in [[Ludwigshafen]], [[Germany]], when she was 15 years old. She was born in [[Berlin]] and was christened '''Johanna Klara Eleonore Renner'''. Her father was Wilhelm Renner, who headed the employment office at [[HASAG]] that developed the successful one-man anti-tank weapon, the [[Panzerfaust]].<ref>[http://www.conne-island.de/nf/107/21.html Nazi history in Leipzig] conne-island.de Retrieved March 23, 2010 {{de icon}}</ref> Later, she chose the portmanteau "Hannelore" to be used as her first name. In the days following Germany's defeat in [[World War II]], at the age of 12, Hannelore Kohl was [[Rape during the occupation of Germany|raped]] by [[Red Army]] soldiers and subsequently “thrown out of a window like a sack of potatoes by the Russians.”<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2005190/Wife-ex-German-chancellor-Helmut-Kohl-raped-age-12-Russian-soldiers.html Wife of ex-German chancellor Helmut Kohl 'raped at the age of 12 by Russian soldiers'], [[Daily Mail]], June 18, 2011</ref><ref>http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2011/06/20/hannelore-kohl-wife-of-former-german-chancellor-was-raped-by-russian-troops-115875-23212991/</ref><ref>http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2003/01/the-wartime-toll-on-germany/2661/</ref> In addition to the obvious psychological impact, the attacks left her with a fractured vertebra and back pain for the rest of her life.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-11/kohl-s-wife-suffered-war-rape-trauma-life-in-his-big-shadow-german-books.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Catherine | last=Hickley | title=Kohl's Wife Suffered War Rape Trauma, Life in His Large Shadow | date=July 11, 2011}}</ref> In order to help others with similar injuries, in 1983 she founded the Kuratorium ZNS, a foundation that helps those with trauma-induced injuries to the [[central nervous system]], and became its president. On 5 July 2001, Kohl was found dead at age 68 in her [[Ludwigshafen]] home. She had apparently committed [[suicide]] with an overdose of sleeping pills, after years of suffering from what she had claimed to be a very rare and painful [[photo allergy]] induced by an earlier [[penicillin]] treatment that had forced her to avoid practically all sunlight for years. In 2005, the Kuratorium ZNS was renamed ZNS - Hannelore Kohl Stiftung in her honor. However, journalist [[Andrew Gimson]], writing in ''[[The Spectator]]'',<ref>[http://www.spectator.co.uk/print/politics/all/9161/married-to-a-monster.thtml "Married to a monster"], [[The Spectator]], 28 July 2001</ref> cast doubt upon the official version of events. Similar questions were also raised by the German newsmagazine ''[[Stern (magazine)|Stern]]'' and the [[BBC]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1436219.stm "German media split by suicide"] [[BBC]] (12 July 2001).
